div1.p: Carter explains the final work continues and that she has received help from members of the Catalogue Division of the Library of Congress.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, October 18, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 18, 1928
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report another week of intensive, and very satisfactory
work, Miss Brown and I having traced several references, which we had been told it
was impossible to verify. This by a research man in the line we were pursuing. We
feel quite elated in consequence. I have also had a most delightful interview with
Dr. L. O. Howard and done some work with his Chief Librarian, which I hope will lead
to clearing up at least one of our remaining entomological references. As I said be-
fore, each remaining reference is a problem in itself now, all ordinary methods of
attempted verification having been exhausted long since. In this connection, Dr.
Martell, Chief of the Catalogue Division of the Library of Congress, and Dr. Koenig,
Assistant Chief, have been most kind and helpful, both in thieeir suggestions and the actual
work they have done for us. Dr. Martell is just back from Italy where he was asked to
help start the re-catagloging of the Vatican Library, as he is a world authority on the
subject, as well as a great scholar.

I am now again working at both Libraries, using that of the Surgeon General, by
means of my invaluable pass, mainly either early in the morning or on Sundays, and the Library of
Congress in between times. It makes life even more strenuous than usual, especially
as Miss Brown and I work at my apartment at night also, but now that we have to “fill
orders” for Dr. Frost, in addition to the work on the remaining references it takes
“all the time there is” to keep up.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
